prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum: Overall Submm Emission: target #1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation for PG 0026+129 for the overall continuum emission in Band 7 with a resolution of 1 arcsecond and sensitivity of 0.1 mJy.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Target Selection: We selected these 5 quasars out of the original sample of 8 quasars in Young et al. (2013) which have HST images and resolved host galaxy emission line maps. The other 3 quasars in Young et al. (2013) are not visible by ALMA and thus left out.
Observed Frequency and Band Width: We choose Band 7 to minimize the effects of atmospheric absorption while staying as blue as possible in the Rayleigh-Jeans tail of the dust thermal emission. This is to keep the integration time at a moderate level while achieving the desired sensitivity. A single continuum is sufficient for our science goal, especially considering that in the ~800 micron wavelength regime these PG quasars currently do not have any observations, and our proposed ALMA observation will bridge the gap between the archival Herschel data and the radio.
Angular Resolution and LAS: As illustrated by the maps shown in our scientific justification, the influential radius of quasar feedback is contained within 2 arcsec by 2 arcsec for all of our five targets, and thus the LAS choice of 2 arcsec. An angular resolution of 1 arcsec will be sufficient to tell if the sub-mm emission comes from a very compact region within 1 kpc of the quasar, or has an extended nature. We do not aim to resolve detailed features of the dust emission under this science goal (see Resolved Sub-Mm Emission science goal for our plan for a pilot study of resolved dust emission for two of our five targets).
Sensitivity: We require the sensitivity per synthesized beam to be 0.1 mJy. We estimated the continuum emission at 336.5 GHz to be 0.5 mJy to a few mJy for these five targets. Our estimates are based on SED fittings using archival photometry available in the NIR and MIR (from NED) with the T-alpha-beta model (see Blain et al. 2003 and Dai et al. 2012), with fixed beta at 1.0-2.0 as commonly assumed in similar studied. The value beta modifies the slope of the Rayleigh-Jeans tail due to frequency-dependent dust emissivity, and because the FIR region is usually poorly observed, it is commonly an assumed prior in SED fitting for quasars. Our proposed ALMA observation will be able to pin down the value of beta for these five quasars.
Dynamic Range: Though the sub-mm emission from the quasar at the very center may dominate the flux, we do not expect the dynamic range to be an issue. First, as illustrated by the line diagnostic maps in our scientific justification, the power of the quasar extends to large physical scale up to 1 kpc. Similarly, the dust emission powered by the quasar is also unlikely to be only confined within the very vicinity of the quasar. Second, based on the star formation rate estimates for these 5 quasar hosts, we expect at least 10% or even more of the FIR luminosity originates from the more extended star formation component. Thus the flux contrast between the quasar at the very center and the extended component is expected to be moderate (tens to hundreds at most).
Overall, this project is well-suited for ALMA Early Science. With a very moderate ALMA time (less than 6 hours including calibrations), we can achieve significant and unique science goals which directly address the important missing piece of the FIR puzzle of quasars and host galaxies.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum: Resolved Submm Emission for 2 PG Quasars
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High resolution (0.122 arcsecond) and high sensitivity (0.03 mJy) observation for PG 1244+026 and PG 1307+085 for a resolved submm map in Band 7 continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In our best effort to resolve the dust emission in the selected two quasar host galaxies, we exploit ALMA's capability of providing simultaneously very high angular resolution and high sensitivity.
Target Selection: These two quasars are selected out of our entire sample of five quasars because: 1. according to the line-diagnosis maps, they clearly show a mixture of quasar and star formation components spatially separated from each other; 2. their star formation rate predicted by the FIR emission exceeds the amount expected from the line emission significantly, which indicates that quasar contributes to some of the FIR energy; 3. they appear to have structure on the scale of approximately 0.25 arcsec, which matches our resolution requirement.
Angular Resolution and Sensitivity: We set angular resolution requirement to be 0.25 arcsec (5 pixels on our HST images) in order to achieve a balance between spatially resolving interesting features and retaining enough surface brightness for robust detection. If all the sub-mm flux (estimated to be 0.5 to a few mJy) were to evenly distributed among the central 1 arcsec radius or so, then we would have marginal detection within each angular resolution element (> 0.03 mJy per synthesized beam). However, it is very likely that the dust is clumpy, with some central concentration and also tracing out the star formation regions. Thus we expect at least a couple robust detections of resolved feature at the center and/or associated with the quasar-powered or star-formation-powered regions further out. The 'missing' flux due to the choice of high angular resolution can be accounted for using the total flux detected in the previous sciences goals with 1 arcsec angular resolution observations.
LAS: We chose LAS to be 1 arcsec, as most of the emission line power comes within this radius (see the figure in scientific justification document). Thus we do not expect the clumpy dust feature to exceed this size.
Observations in the sub-mm band with both such high angular resolution and high sensitivity is only possible with ALMA. If this pilot study with these two quasars prove to be successful, future mapping of quasar host galaxies will open up a new window in studying the star formation and quasar feedback in unprecedented details.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to make far-infrared (FIR) continuum observations of quasar host galaxies with ALMA for use in tandem with existing HST observations to resolve the ongoing debate about the origin of FIR emission from quasars. Many earlier works report FIR thermal dust emission from quasars, but it is ambiguous what source of energy heats the dust. The most likely candidates are the UV light from young stars and the UV power-law continuum from the quasar. In an earlier paper we presented HST observations of quasar host galaxies with which, after careful PSF removed, we derived emission-line excitation maps which identify the source of line excitation via line ratio diagnostics. By using ALMA to trace out the thermal dust emission in a subsample of these quasar hosts and overlaying this data with our excitation maps we will determine how much of the FIR emission is due to the quasar and how much is due to star formation. Because these HST observations are the only study so far that unambiguously identifies the ISM energy source on a region-by-region basis, we are the only group positioned to take advantage of ALMA's spatial resolution in this manner.
